9:I[37277,["/_next/static/chunks/780ed9f12bd597e3.js","/_next/static/chunks/93fb432403aebbdd.js","/_next/static/chunks/6ed45c29e6db9297.js","/_next/static/chunks/ca6e69eece0158a1.js","/_next/static/chunks/c6ed05d45582b587.js"],"Separator"]

12:"$Sreact.suspense"
2:Teae,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Recipe","name":"Tamales Norteños","description":"Northern Argentine tamales made with corn dough stuffed with spiced beef, wrapped in dried corn husks and steamed. A labor-intensive dish traditionally made in large batches by the whole family.","image":"https://expatsargentina.com/images/recipes/tamales-nortenos.webp","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Expats Argentina"},"datePublished":"2025-01-01","prepTime":"PT130M","cookTime":"PT2M","totalTime":"PT3M","recipeYield":"12 servings","recipeCategory":"main","recipeCuisine":"Argentine","keywords":"tamales nortenos recipe, argentine tamales, tamales argentinos, tamales salteños, northern argentine tamales","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","calories":"380 calories","proteinContent":"18g","carbohydrateContent":"42g","fatContent":"16g"},"recipeIngredient":["For the dough (masa): 500g (3½ cups) fine cornmeal (harina de maíz) or masa harina","For the dough (masa): 200ml (3/4 cup + 2 tbsp) beef broth, warm","For the dough (masa): 100g (7 tbsp) beef fat (grasa de pella) or lard, melted","For the dough (masa): 1 tsp salt","For the dough (masa): 1 tsp smoked paprika","For the dough (masa): 1/2 tsp ground cumin","For the filling: 500g (1 lb) beef chuck, cut into small cubes","For the filling: 1 large onion, finely diced","For the filling: 2 green onions (cebolla de verdeo), chopped","For the filling: 2 tsp ground cumin","For the filling: 2 tsp sweet paprika","For the filling: 1 tsp red pepper flakes (ají molido)","For the filling: Salt and pepper to taste","For the filling: 2 tbsp beef fat or oil for cooking","For wrapping: 24 large dried corn husks, soaked in hot water for 1 hour","For wrapping: Kitchen twine or strips of corn husk for tying"],"recipeInstructions":[{"@type":"HowToStep","position":1,"text":"Prepare the filling first: heat beef fat in a skillet over medium heat. Brown the beef cubes in batches, then remove and set aside."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":2,"text":"In the same pan, sauté onion until soft. Add green onions, cumin, paprika, and red pepper flakes. Cook 2 minutes until fragrant."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":3,"text":"Return the beef to the pan, season with salt and pepper, add a splash of water, and simmer covered for 15 minutes. The beef should be tender but not falling apart. Let cool."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":4,"text":"Make the dough: combine cornmeal, salt, paprika, and cumin. Add melted beef fat and warm broth gradually, mixing with your hands until you have a soft, pliable dough that holds together. It should be the consistency of thick hummus."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":5,"text":"Drain the corn husks and pat dry. Lay two husks overlapping to form a wider surface."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":6,"text":"Spread about 3 tablespoons of dough onto the center of the husks, forming a rectangle about 4x3 inches."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":7,"text":"Place 2 tablespoons of the beef filling in the center of the dough."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":8,"text":"Fold one side of the husk over the filling, then the other side. Fold the bottom up and the top down to form a packet. Tie securely with twine or a strip of corn husk."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":9,"text":"Repeat with remaining dough and filling — you should get about 12 tamales."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":10,"text":"Stand the tamales upright in a large steamer pot (open end up). Steam over simmering water for 1.5-2 hours."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":11,"text":"The tamales are done when the dough pulls away cleanly from the husk when you peel one open."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":12,"text":"Let rest 10 minutes before serving. Unwrap at the table."}]}0:{"buildId":"XJ7f5RvYDcX4yjbAXmNYG","rsc":["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-orange-50 to-white","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$2"}}],"$L3","$L4","$L5","$L6"]}],null,"$L7"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
3:["$","div",null,{"className":"border-b bg-white/80 backdrop-blur-sm sticky top-0 z-40 print:hidden","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-5xl mx-auto px-4 py-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-center justify-between","children":["$","$L8",null,{"href":"/food/recipes","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-arrow-left w-4 h-4","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1l729n",{"d":"m12 19-7-7 7-7"}],["$","path","x3x0zl",{"d":"M19 12H5"}],"$undefined"]}],"All Recipes"],"data-slot":"button","data-variant":"ghost","data-size":"sm","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center whitespace-nowrap text-sm font-medium transition-all disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:opacity-50 [&_svg]:pointer-events-none [&_svg:not([class*='size-'])]:size-4 shrink-0 [&_svg]:shrink-0 outline-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive hover:bg-accent hover:text-accent-foreground dark:hover:bg-accent/50 h-8 rounded-md px-3 has-[>svg]:px-2.5 gap-2","ref":null}]}]}]}]

e:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-lg","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 Don't reduce it."}]]}],["$","li","1",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Make tamales as a group activity — it's the traditional way and much more efficient (and fun) with extra hands."}]]}],["$","li","2",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"If the dough feels dry, add more broth a tablespoon at a time. If too wet, add more cornmeal."}]]}]]}]}]]}]
1f:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","id":"history","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-history w-5 h-5 text-orange-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1357e3",{"d":"M3 12a9 9 0 1 0 9-9 9.75 9.75 0 0 0-6.74 2.74L3 8"}],["$","path","1xhq8a",{"d":"M3 3v5h5"}],["$","path","1fdv2h",{"d":"M12 7v5l4 2"}],"$undefined"]}],"The Story Behind the Dish"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700 leading-relaxed","children":"Tamales have been made in the Argentine northwest for centuries, predating Spanish colonization. The Diaguita and other indigenous peoples wrapped corn paste around wild game and cooked it in embers. Spanish colonists added beef and pork, and the tamaleada — a communal tamal-making gathering — became a social tradition. In Salta and Jujuy, families still make hundreds of tamales in a single session, with everyone assigned a role: mixing, filling, wrapping, or tying."}]}]]}]
20:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Storage & Leftovers"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-0","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Refrigerate cooked tamales for up to 4 days. Freeze for up to 3 months. Reheat by steaming for 15-20 minutes from frozen."}]}]]}]
